Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire

No. 2

Pioneer Experiences: A General Questionnaire

A word of explanation to the reader:

It is difficult to answer a general questionnaire in pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences or memories as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences or they may prove impossible for you to answer. So don't worry about leaving blank spaces.

If there is not sufficient space to answer the question, write extra sheets of paper. If there is not sufficient space to answer the question, write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Western Canadian Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Pieta: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Get?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ).

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

- All pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
- Pioneer housing
- Pioneer whistling and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Board
University of Saskatchewan
Saskatoon, Sask.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCE: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A work of compilation by the PIONEER HISTORY COMMITTEE

It is difficult to traverse a general questionnaire so pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has equally the same experiences. Some of the questions here will not apply to your answers, but others may prove impossible for you to answer, and don't worry about leaving blank spaces. The best thing to do is to describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Eastern Canada before 1874 and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or supply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Pioneers," What Did Western Canadian pioneers have to say? is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ).

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire on other subjects will be printed at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

To Saska - April, 1905

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. If you rather have someone else do the writing at your dictation, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name: ROBERT ROYCROFT
2. Your address: 9 HAUNAVON
3. Date: JUNE 22, 1905
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): IRELAND
5. What was your father's name and occupation? THOMAS ROYCROFT
6. When did you come to Saska toawan? (Give month and year): APRIL 1905
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saska toawan: NEW YORK, NEW YORK
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to state your birth date or question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a child")
9. What were your reasons for coming West?
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it?)

The same instinct that brings the birds North has as any man. Country offers opportunity to a young man. And that what do mind today is opportunity, not all a go positions & who hundred but to get & come home.
Robert Raycroft

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child")
9. What were your reasons for coming West?
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it?)

The same instinct that brings the birds North has brought me here. As any new country offers opportunity to a young man, I decided to make the move today. It is a spontaneous decision, not a calculated one.

My plan is to work hard and put it into practice. I am confident that I will succeed.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

They thought I was too adventurous in my age.

By myself.

14. What incidents of the journey do you remember? Please list them in order:

a. Boarded on the Canadian Pacific Railway at 5:45 p.m.
b. Met yard on Good Friday, April 1898, Boarded at 6:00 p.m.
c. Stayed here until the next day, April 19th, Boarded at 7:00 p.m.
d. Left with my family on the 24th, Boarded at 8:00 p.m.
e. When I came, you could see the electric light in the house.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

Glenbow, 1 year, Regina, 5 years and in Okanagan, April 1913

25. When was the first car used in the community?  
1907 - A Mitchell

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?  
None

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?  
1906 - 40 miles

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)  
No, as I had a store, a grocery store next door but we hauled our supplies 40 miles.

29. How often did you shop in the early days?  
Many folks too supplied with them to the Homestead that lasted 3 months.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?  
As soon as the railway came there was some attraction, they came from as much as 70 miles.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues?  
What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.  
I never did, and mail order was never successful as the mails were not very regular - not very safe and besides the mail order couldn't operate without the local dealer to display samples so there are very few can judge goods from a picture until they see a sample or some new counter.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

I took to municipal life early and was Deputy Mayor of Langley in 1917 & first Mayor of Sherrington 1918. Councilor for 7 terms also on the school board 2 terms & ran school 24 hrs. Have Hot & Cold water for any children to get a bath and a nice shower. Bath rooms to do it in & I was the originator.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district, mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.)

We too have a fine town. A heated swimming pool 4,000 gals of water heated by the two big engines that produce the electric power of the town & district for 100 miles around.

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live and occupations.

Have 3 children: Theo Edward, Managing Director, Wholesale Hotelier, Regina; University training, a good musician; Mary Esther, the wife of a local lawyer in Murrays Bay; Edith, teacher, supervisor of Education in Regina and has just completed graduating from the University of Alberta with a Masters Degree and is the referee of the Regina Dept of Education.

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

I think the change of Government was that changed the composition of the whole state of affairs. It changed the manner of our lives.
